metadata.case_name: Krishna Prasad v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Krishna Prasad assessee-appellant along with his father Krishnaswami Naidu and brother C. Krishna Kumar formed a Hindu undivided family up to October 30, 1958.
Partition between Krishnaswami Naidu and his two sons on October 30, 1958; assessee got some house properties and vacant sites.
Partition recognised by department; order under section 25-A of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 passed recognising partition with effect from November 1, 1958.
Assessee was unmarried on date of partition and during relevant period i.e. year ending March 31, 1964.
Up to assessment year 1963-64, assessee assessed in status of individual.
For assessment year 1964-65, assessee filed return showing status as individual but claimed assessment in status of Hindu undivided family.
Income-tax Officer did not accept claim, held status as individual.
Order of Income-tax Officer affirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Appellate Tribunal.
At instance of assessee, question referred to Mysore High Court under section 256(1) of Income-tax Act, 1961.
Mysore High Court answered question in affirmative in favour of revenue and against assessee.
No other person besides assessee is member of alleged family; assessee is absolute owner of property received on partition and can deal with it as he wishes.
No female member in existence entitled to maintenance or capable of adopting son.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the assessee was rightly assessed in the status of an individual for the assessment year 1964-65?

Whether an unmarried male Hindu on partition of a joint Hindu family can be assessed in the status of a Hindu undivided family even though no other person besides him is a member of the alleged family.

petitioner_arguments.text: Assessee claimed that he should be assessed in the status of a Hindu undivided family for 1964-65.

Reliance on Anant Bhikappa Patil v. Shankar Ramchandra Patil to argue that a Hindu joint family cannot be finally brought to an end while it is possible to add a male member; implicit that single member (widow) constituted family.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Anant Bhikappa Patil v. Shankar Ramchandra Patil, AIR 1943 PC 196

respondent_arguments.text: Assessee's status is that of an individual, not Hindu undivided family.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 2(31) and Section 4 of Income-tax Act, 1961

court_reasoning.text: A single individual cannot constitute a Hindu undivided family; family denotes a group, plurality of persons essential.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Family connotes a group of people related by blood or marriage; single person remains individual.

court_reasoning.text: Hindu undivided family under Income-tax Act used in sense of Hindu joint family under Hindu law; can consist of single male and widows, but assessment as HUF requires two or more members.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Share on partition is ancestral only as regards male issue; assessee sole coparcener, absolute owner.

court_reasoning.text: Status determined by present realities, not future possibilities like adoption.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Excursions to speculation not permissible for income-tax assessment.

court_reasoning.text: Anant Bhikappa Patil case concerns widow's adoption power after sole coparcener's death; adopted son's rights relate back, so no single member family during period.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Case not applicable as question of single individual as HUF not before Judicial Committee.

holdings.text: Unmarried male Hindu after partition, with no other members, cannot be assessed as Hindu undivided family; correctly assessed as individual.
Hindu undivided family in Income-tax Act requires plurality of persons; single person is individual.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gowli Buddanna v. Commissioner of Income-tax Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: Court refrained from opining if single member HUF is taxable entity.

precedents_cited.case_name: Attorney-General of Ceylon v. Arunachalam Chettiar Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Hindu undivided family in Income-tax Act in sense of Hindu joint family under Hindu law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Madras v. Ram Ar. Ar. Veerappa Chettiar
precedents_cited.relevance: Hindu joint family need not have male member; continues with widows if property undivided.

precedents_cited.case_name: Anant Bhikappa Patil v. Shankar Ramchandra Patil
precedents_cited.relevance: Power of widow to adopt not defeated by death of sole coparcener; but adopted son rights relate back, no single member family.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Charging of tax on persons including individual and HUF; HUF distinct from individual; reference to High Court.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; assessee held to be individual and not Hindu undivided family for assessment year 1964-65; High Court judgment affirmed.

key_quotes.text: A family consisting of a single individual is a contradiction in terms.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding that single person cannot constitute HUF.

key_quotes.text: Plurality of persons is an essential attribute of a family. A single person, male or female, does not constitute a family.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines essence of 'family' under Income-tax law.

key_quotes.text: In order to determine the status of the assessee for the purpose of income-tax, we have to look to the realities as they exist at present and it would not be correct to project into the matter future possibilities.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects speculation on future members like adoption.
